A ring homomorphism $\varphi: A \longrightarrow B$ is integral if every element $b \in B$ is integral over $A$ in the way described in the definition of an integral element over a ring.

A ring homomorphism $\varphi: R \longrightarrow R'$ is called an isomorphism if it admits an inverse, i.e., there exists a ring homomorphism $\psi: R' \longrightarrow R$ such that $\psi \circ \varphi=\mathrm{id}_{R}$ and $\varphi \circ \psi=\mathrm{id}_{R'}$. This is equivalent to $\varphi$ being bijective.
Does the concept of a/an Integral Ring Homomorphism need to be defined for a definition of a/an Ring Isomorphism to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
The concept of a Ring Isomorphism involves a bijective ring homomorphism that has an inverse which is also a ring homomorphism. This definition requires the homomorphism to be both surjective (onto) and injective (one-to-one), ensuring that every element in the target ring corresponds to exactly one element in the source ring, and vice versa.

On the other hand, an Integral Ring Homomorphism involves a condition where every element of the target ring B is integral over the source ring A. This concept is related to the algebraic dependencies of elements in B over A, and does not inherently involve the bijectiveness or the existence of an inverse homomorphism.

Thus, the definition of a Ring Isomorphism does not depend on the concept of an Integral Ring Homomorphism. The two concepts operate independently in the context of ring theory. A Ring Isomorphism focuses on the structural and functional correspondence between two rings, while an Integral Ring Homomorphism focuses on the algebraic properties of elements with respect to their pre-images.
